_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

The Osceola Food LLC facility located in Osceola, Iowa is a processor of pork and other meats. The primary purpose of this facility is to process these meats into food products for distribution to retailers.  A product distribution center located next to the plant is included with this RMP.  The maintenance and refrigeration processes at the distribution center are managed by the plant. A contracted firm manages the distribution center and non-plant employees that are used to move product. We have a strong commitment to operate our facility in a safe and responsible manner.

Independent ammonia refrigeration processes exist at the plant and distribution center.  Ammonia is contained in a closed loop systems; it is designed to remain inside the piping and vessels in our facility.  We believe that ammonia provides the safest and most efficient cooling choice for our operation.

Ammonia is classified by EPA as a toxic chemical and it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the health threat to our own workers, and reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia, safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.


A. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Policies

An accidental release prevention program has been in place since the purchase of the facility in 1995. The facility was designed and constructed and maintained in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines, and is in compliance with State codes.  The facility was expanded and updated (1996) which included replacing the high pressure ammonia receiver with a new tank and associated piping system.  Furthermore, additions to the process have occur

red as production warrants.  The equipment reliability has not been an issue, but the expansion does provide newer equipment and the benefits associated with new facilities. This food processing facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable State codes and regulations.

We take many precautions to prevent or minimize accidental releases of ammonia from the refrigeration system.  These precautions include safety controls (alarms and automatic shutdown devices) which are designed to identify and prevent potentially unsafe conditions like pressure increases that could cause a system failure. Company machinery room policy, respiratory policy, a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the systems, a training program designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel, and emergency response procedures that enable trained personnel to respond quickly to system upsets.

The Manager of Plant Engineering is responsible for the management of these ammonia safety programs.


B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Ammonia is the only substance covered by the Accidental Release Prevention Regulations that is handled at this facility. 



C. Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program 

The facility has an accident release prevention program that complies with Occupational Safety and Health Act's Process Safety Management Standard and EPA's Risk Management Program Rule. The prevention program consists of the following elements: 

¿ Employee Participation Program: 
The Plant has an overall safety program that includes employee awareness, involvement and training in all parts of the Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management (RM) Program to minimize the potential for an accident or incident involving the ammonia refrigeration equipment.
¿ Process Safety Information: 
Ammonia refrigeration equipment manuals and plant design tec

hnical specifications including piping diagrams are on file. The purpose of compiling written process safety information is to enable the employees involved in operating the ammonia refrigeration system to identify and understand the system and features of all its components and the hazards posed by the system.  
¿ Process Hazard Analysis: 
A process hazard analysis (PHA) re-validation was conducted in 2015 for the plant and  distribution center.  A team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the existing refrigeration system in depth and developed recommendations to improve the safety and operability of the system.  The PHA addressed What-if factors such as:  (1) process hazards; (2) previous incidents; (3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards; (4) the consequence of control failure; (5) facility siting; (6) human factors; and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible safety and health effects of control system failures.  
¿ Operating Procedures: 
Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) were prepared to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The SOPs include procedures for normal operations, startup, shutdown, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.  
¿ Training Program: 
All ammonia refrigeration operators are trained using a formal training program. This program consists of having an effective preventive maintenance program and comprehensive employee initial and refresher training to insure equipment integrity. 

The overall purpose of training personnel is to enable them to safely and efficiently operate and maintain the ammonia refrigeration system and increase employee awareness of potential hazards.
 

¿ Contractor Safety Program: 
Contractors that are used to work on or adjacent to the refrigeration system are pre-qualified based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and sta

s been one incident at the facility that is listed on our 5 year accident history.  This incident resulted in a Dr. visit.  After the initial visit there were no restrictions, no effects and only one follow up visit to verify.  This happened in May of 2012.  
We have replaced the manual control of evaporator defrost with automated controls to prevent a similar incident in the future.
 
E. Description of the Emergency Response Program 

The emergency response program is based upon federal guidelines as they apply to this facility.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority, local emergency response agencies, and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.  The facility emergency response plan is based on all known applicable regulations and requirements.  The emergency response plan has been discussed with the Osceola Fire Department and other agencies involved with response.  Representatives of the Osceola Fire Department visit this plant on an annual basis. 

The facility has a trained team of emergency responders that are available to respond to any ammonia release.  This trained staffs are skilled at responding to a release and isolating problem areas within the ammonia refrigeration system.  

F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

Osceola Food has demonstrated and plans several changes to improve employee and environmental safety,  including but not limited to:
-       Machinery Room upgrades including ventilation to IIAR recommendations for Program 2;
-   	Replacement of equipment prior to failure, i.e. condensers, evaporators, piping, and insulation;
-	Guarding of ammonia water chiller outside boiler room to prevent possible impacts.

ndards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely.  Each of these contractors is evaluated from a safety perspective.
The purpose of the Contractor Program is to help ensure that contractors, subcontractors, and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with a process covered by the Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard and the Risk Management Program (RM Program) Rule. This awareness should lead to reduced risks of accidents, and thus improved safety, for both contract employees and the company's employees.
¿ Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures: 
See comments under Management of Change  
¿ Mechanical Integrity Program: 
The Plant has a program for replacement of all Safety Relief Valves on a 5 year interval as recommended by IIAR.  We also have a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the system.  The purpose of a mechanical integrity program is to maintain ammonia refrigeration equipment so that a catastrophic release of ammonia is avoided.
¿ Hot Work Permit Procedures: 
The plant has implemented a Hot Work permit program including training.  
¿ Management of Change Procedures: 
For projects, a management of change procedure and a pre-startup safety review are in place to ensure that system changes or expansions are safe and that the changes are consistent with the engineering design and in condition to be operated prior to startup.  
¿ Incident Investigation Procedures: 
An incident investigation program is in place at the plant to review incidents and implement any identified improvement(s) to reduce future potential for new incidents to occur.  
¿ Compliance Audit Procedures: 
At least every three years a full program audit is conducted to identify any elements of the PSM and RM Program that do not meet the requirements of the PSM Standard and RM Program Rule and to provide a means of responding to deficiencies found by the auditors.
